title: NOT REAL NEWS: Photos not of officers injured by migrants | AP ...
htmlTitle: NOT REAL NEWS: Photos not of officers injured by migrants | AP ...
snippet: Oct 24, 2018 ... His photo, along with two others, were miscaptioned to say that Mexican police were being brutalized by members of the migrant caravan.
htmlSnippet: Oct 24, 2018 ... His photo, along with two others, were miscaptioned to say that Mexican police were being brutalized by members of the migrant caravan.

metatags.og:description: A set of three photos of injured federal police officers in Mexico were not taken after confrontations with migrants making their way in a caravan from Central America to the U.S., despite posts circulating on social media. In the most prominent photo, an officer is bleeding from a head wound. Gustavo Aguado Butanda, a local photographer in the Mexican state of Michoacan, told The Associated Press that he took the photo on Oct. 15, 2012, in Tiripetio. Butanda said that police had entered a school in the town during a clash involving "normalistas," a group of students protesting modernization of curriculums.
metatags.twitter:title: NOT REAL NEWS: Photos not of officers injured by migrants
metatags.og:title: NOT REAL NEWS: Photos not of officers injured by migrants

In the most prominent photo, an officer is bleeding from a head wound. Gustavo Aguado Butanda, a local photographer in the Mexican state of Michoacan, told The Associated Press that he took the photo on Oct. 15, 2012, in Tiripetio. Butanda said that police had entered a school in the town during a clash involving "normalistas," a group of students protesting modernization of curriculums.

claimreview.claimreviewed: Viral photos show “Mexican police are being brutalized" by Central American immigrants as they travel through Mexico toward the U.S.

metatags.apple-mobile-web-app-title: FactCheck.org - A Project of The Annenberg Public Policy Center
metatags.og:description: Q: Are the viral photos of Mexican police being “brutalized” by Central American immigrants accurate? A: No. Those images are old and unrelated to the group of immigrants seeking to come to the U.S. FULL ANSWER As thousands of Central American immigrants march toward the U.S. border, many claiming to flee violence and corruption, misinformation about the so-called “caravan” abounds. Viral posts this week, for example, have spread images purporting to depict severe attacks on police by the immigrants.
metatags.twitter:creator: @factcheckdotorg
metatags.author: Angelo Fichera
metatags.og:title: Graphic Photos Falsely Linked to 'Caravan' - FactCheck.org

metatags.og:description: A new migrant caravan is heading to the United States. The caravan, which organizers say numbers thousands of people, formed in the Honduran city of San Pedro Sula on October 13 and crossed into Guatemala on Monday.
